metadata.title: Exudative hyperresponsiveness of the airway microcirculation in seasonal allergic rhinitis

abstract.text: Backs^ronnd Mucosal exudation of plasma is a non-injurious, physiological response of the aitway rtiicrocitculation to different inllamtnatory processes. The exudative response is similar in the nose and bronchi and exudation occurs iti both allergic asthtna and rhinitis. The cxtidative response is a specific end-organ limclion of the inucosa[ microeirciilation that may be altered in airway diseases. Ohjeetive This study exatnincs the hypothesis of altered responsiveness of the superficial airway tnicrocitculalion to vascular permeability-increasirtg challenges in sustaitied allergic inflammation. Methods Fourteen patients with birch-pollen induced allergic rhinitis were studied for 7 weeks during a Swedish birch-pollen seasoti. Nasal symptoms (itching, snee/ing. blockage, atid discharge) were recorded and the occurrence of pollen was determined. The plasma exudation response was examined by topical histamine challenges at the etid (May) and well out of (Decetnber) the seasoti. Challenge and lavage were carried out concotiittantly using a 'tiasal pooT-device. The utiilatcral nasal cavity was tilled for consecutive 10 minute periods with saline and two concentrations of histamine (80//g niL and 40()//gmL). The lavage fluid levels of different-sized plastna proteins (albumin-66000D. fihrinogen-340000D. and ormacroglobulin-725 0()UD) were detemiined. Results The pollen season was mild resulting in only minor nasal symptoms. Histatnine produced exudation of all plastna proteins across the microvascular epithelial barriers with particularly strong correlation between the levels of albumin and <>2-tnacroglobulin (r = 0 9S: P < 0 00!). The exudative response to histamine was concentration-dependent (P<0 05) and. furthermore, it was significantly greater late into the season compared with outside the pollen season (albumin: P < 0 05. hbrinogen: P<{)()5. n.-macroglobulin: /'<001). Conelusion We conclude that histamine produced concentratioti-depetident nasal airway exudation of bulk plasma in subjects with seasonal rhinitis and that this response is abnortnally great during the pollen season. Whether angiogenesis or increased responsivetiess of the microvascular etidothelium may explain this phenomenon now remains unknown. We suggest that a microvascular exudative hyperrespotisiveness may characterize allergic airway disease.

body_text.text: Actilc itiflamtnutory challenges produce several physiological effects in the airways. Increased blood-llow. iticreased secretion, altered inucociliary activity, increased mierovascular pcrtiicability. and cough/sneezes may be produced. Most of these are not specific to inflammation since they can be produced by irritants that merely evoke neural activity. However, one tissue response that is rather specific to inflammation is increased vascular pernieabiiity [1.2] . This effect is produced by allergen, occupational agents, viral infections, and select media-tcM"s [3 6 ]. It is not produced by methacholine [4.7] nor is it. in human airways, produced by potent neural agents such as capsaicin [8] and nicotine [9] .

At mucosal inffammatory challenges or processes the profuse superficial airway microcirciilation releases bulk plasma. The plastita exudate distributes in the lamina propria. It moves readily across the epitlielial basement membrane and thcti up between individual epithelial cells. At this latter site only a very small increase in the hydrostatic pressure (about 5cm H^O) [10.11] . most likely caused by the exudate itself, will create valve-like paracellular pathways for prompt luminal entry of almost non-sieved bulk plasma, (The plasma exudate iticreasingly contaitis tiewly fonned oligoproteins, poptides, and. perhaps, tiiore ffuid.) The permeability of the subepithelial microcirculation can thus be monitored by the amount of exudative indices appearing on the mucosal surface per unit time [4] .

At sustained inllatiimatory processes specific endorgans of the airway mucosa. such as the innervation, tlie seeretory apparatus, and the microcirculation. may develop an altered responsiveness. We have speculated that speeific endorgan hyperresponsiveness may characterize rhinitis and asthma or sub-groups of patients sutTering from these inffammatory diseases [2] . The clinical experimental techniques currently available seem U) allow specific measurements of end-organ functions in the nasal airways whereas the bronchial response is Irequentiy reeorded as a "black box' sum effect of partly unknown components. Furthermore, it is possible that intlammatory disease meehanisms may be similar in nasal and bronchial mucosa [2] . For example, in both nasal and bronchial airways of allergie subjeets. topical allergen challenge itiduces mucosal exudation of bulk plasma [2.12.13] . Additionally, we have previously demonstrated that an exudative hyperresponsiveness develops during a coronavirus-indueed common eold [14] .

The hypothesis tested in this study concerns the possibility that the superficial airway microcirculation may change its responsiveness to vascular permeabilityincreasing challenges during sustained allergic inllamma-tion. To examine this potential disease characteristic histamine-challenges were carried out outside and late into the Swedish birch pollen season in subjects with seasonal allergic rhinitis. Based on our previous experience v\ ith histamine. we have selected two eoncentrations of this amine to produce the plasma exudation response [15] , F'tirthermore. we have used a nasal pool-device that applies, for defined periods of time, the selected histamine concentration on a large and reproducible mucosal surface area. The pool-device then gently, efficiently, and selectively lavages the exposed airway surface [15] .

Fourteen patients with birch pollen induced allergic rhinitis vvcte studied for 7 weeks during the birch pollen season oi' 1991 (from April H until May 26), Histamine challenges and nasal lavages were performed at the end of the pollen season (May 26. i.e. day 49) and well out of the season (December 1991) when the patients were asymptomatic. The levels of albumin, tibrinogen. and oi-maeroglobulin were determined in the lavage fluids.

Nine men and five women between the ages of 19 and 47 years (mean age 26 years) participated in this study. All patients had a history of birch pollen-induced allergie rhinitis, positive skin-prick test, and a positive reaction to nasal challenge with birch pollen. The patients had no other organic manifestations o\' their allergic disease. No drugs were permitted during the stud\ or during a 3 week period before entering the study. All participants gave their infonned consent before entering the study which was approved by the F-thics Committee at Lund University,

Histamine provocation and nasal lavages were performed concomitantly using the 'nasal pool" device method as previously described [15] . Isotonic saline solution (0-9yo) at rootn temperature was used for lavages and challenges, Histamine hydrochloride was added to the saline solution to reach a linal histamine concentration of 80//g mL (H80) and 4()()//g,mL (H400). respectively. While the patient was positioned with the head flexed forward (60 ), the unilateral nasal cavity was gently filled by compressing the nasal pool containers (Volume 15 niL), After two quick saline c 1995 Blackwell Seienue Ltd. Clmknt ami fixptrimcfilid . 25 . ')42-950 lavages (duration: 30s eacli) the dilferent solutions wete kept in the nasal cavity for consecutive lOmin periods and then returned back into the containers (0-lOtnin: saline; I0-20miti: H8(); 20 30min: M400). The weight of the fluid filled containers was recorded before (W|.,) and after (W_,) the lavages. The weight of the etnpty plastic container (W^.) was subtracted and then the recovery (Rec) was calculated; Rec = (W;, -W^)/-{Wf, -W^, , ) X 100. The lavage fluid was thereafter imtnediately centrifugated (65()j;' for lOmin) and frozen (-20 C) until atialysed.

Albumin Albumin was measured using a radioitiitnunoassay. sensitive to 6 25ng tnL. with antiserum (rabbit anti-human albutnin) (Dakopatts, Copenhagen. Denmark) and commercial standard (Calbioehem. San Diego, CA, USA). Iodination was performed using a lactoperoxidase method [16] to a specific acti\ity of 2tiiCi tnnol. Tracer and standards (or samples) were mixed with antiserutn before adding goat anti-rabbit antiserum (Astra Draco. Lund. Sweden). The bound fraction was measured in a gamma counter (Clinigamma) (Pharmacia Diagnostica Norden. Uppsala. Sweden) and the data evaluated using RIA CALC (Pharmacia Diagtiostica Norden, Uppsala, Sweden). The ititra-and intercoefficient of variatioti was 5% and 10%. respectively.

Fihrinogeji Fibrinogen was measured with a radioimtnunoassay sensitive to 2 ng/niL. Iodination was made with the lactoperoxidase method [16] . Rabbit antihutnati Hbrinogen (UCB-Bioproduets SA.. Braine-L'allerud. Belgium) and human fibrinogen (reference substatice) (Sigtna., St Louis. Missouri. USA atid Calbioehem. San Diego. CA. USA) wete u.sed. The samples were treated oti a ultrasonic bath for 15 niiti and centrifuged at 2250i* for lOmin. Standards and samples, respectively, were tnixcd with tracer and antiserum. Separation was accomplished by adding diluted nortnal rabbit serum and goat anti-rabbit IgG (Astra Draco. Lund, Sweden). The bound fraction was measured iti a gatntnacounter (Clinigatnma. Pharmacia Diagnostica Nordeii. Uppsala. Sweden) and the results were calculated using RIA CALC (Pharmacia Diagnostica Norden. Llppsala. Sweden). The intra-and inter-assay coefiicient of variation were 7% and 12%. respectively.

was tneasured with a radioitntnunoassay sensitive to 7-81 ngjnL. Rabbit anti-human (>2-"i*'^^oglobu!in (Prod.nr AO33, Dakopatts. Ct>petiliagen. Dentnark) was used as antiserutn and standard hutnan serum (Prod.nr. 67930S, Behringwerke AG Diagnostica, Marburg, Germany) as standard. Human o^-macroglobulin (Prod.nr 32632, Cappel Organon Teknika, Turnhout, Belgiutn) was ioditiated usitig the lactoperoxidase tnethod [16] . Tracer and standards (or samples) were tnixed with antiserum before adding goat anti-rabbit antiserum (Astra Draco, Lund, Sweden). The bound fraction was measured in a gamma counter (Clinigamma) (Pharmacia Diagnostica Norden. Uppsala, Sweden) and the data evaluated using Multi CALC (Wallac OY. Abo. Fitiland). The mtra-and inter-assay coefftcient of variation were 38-60% and 31 -7-2%., respectively.
The birch pollen occurrence was estimated by a Burkhard pollen trap located in the study area and expressed as the tnean daily nutnber of birch pollen grains per cubic tneter of HItered air.

The participants were equipped with a score chart and estitnated daily their nasal symptoms (blockage, itching, stieezing and seeretion) frotn 0 to 3 (0 = no symptotns. 1 = mild. 2 ^ tnoderatc and 3= severe symptotns) giving a total daily score range from 0 to 12 during the pollen season. At the histamine challenges, blockage and secretion were estimated from 0 to 3 and the number of sneezes were counted during each lOmin provocation.

Non-paratiietric statistics were used. Friedtnan test followed by Wilcoxon signed ratik test. Speartnati rank correlation test was used for calculations of correlation. A /'-value less than 0 05 was considered significant.

All patients ctnnpleted the study. Daily birch pollen counts and nasal sytnplotn scores are presented in Fig. 1 . The birch pollen occurrence was low to moderate and below average values for the region with only one peak above 100 grains/m filtered air. Total birch pollen count (grains/m"' HItered air/year) for the entite pollen season 1991 was only 1285 (mean value for the region during the years 1979-1991 is 2627). The nasal symptotn scores were also low with some enhancement during the last weeks ofthe sttidy period (in comparison with day I the total nasal sytnptoms were significantly increased on (Table 1) ,
body_text.section: Pollen oeeurrenee and daily nasal symptoms

body_text.text: There were no signilicatit seasonal changes in the levels of albumin, fibrinogen or ai-rnacroglobulin in the salitie <on5 challenge (baseline), while the exudative response to hislamine was significantly increased during seasonal pollen exposure tor ull three plasma proteins ( Table 2) . Almost the same statistical significance was obtained if" net changes were compared, i.e. saline lavage fluid levels (baseline) were subtracted from lavage fluid levels in HSO and H400 ( Table 2) . Calculations of correlations between the lavage fluid levels of the plasma proteins were made on the three lavages (saline + H80 + H400) in December and May. The levels of" albumin and rtT-macroglobulin demonstrated a strong correlation at both occasions (r -0 92 and r -0 98 for December and May respectively; P < 0001) (Fig. 3) while the levels of fibrinogen showed much weaker correlations with the other two proteins (values for December and May. respectively: /•-0 48 (P< 0 01) and r-0-76 (P< GOOD for fibrinogen-to-albumin: and /• -0-50 (P<001) and /• = 074 (P < OOOl) lor fibrinogen-to-on-macroglobulin) (Spearman rank correlation coefficient).

The nasal symptom scores increased concentrationdependent on hi.stamine challenge at both occasions (niunber of sneezes: P < 0 05, secretion score: P < 0 001. blockage score: F < 0 001; values for both occasions; !-riedman test). However, neither sneezes, nor scores for nasal secretion or blockage indticed by saline (baseline) or any of the two histamine challenges were significatitly increased late in season compared with values obtained out of season (Wileoxon's signed rank test) (Fig, 4) .

The present study involving subjects with seasonal allergic rhinitis has demonstrated that topical histamine produced concentration-dependent exudation of different-sized plasma proteins (albumin-6600() D: flbrinogen-3400001): and a.-macroglohulin-725()OOD) into the airway lumen both outside and during the pollen season. Also, the correlation between albumin-and (\2macroglobulin-levels in the lavage fluids was very high. strongly supporting the notion that the acute exudation process is of a non-sieved nature [1.2.4] . Despite the mild pollen season, the exudative responsiveness to histamine wa.s significantly increased at the end of the pollen season. This result thus suggests that a novel type of airway hyperresponsiveness. 'exudatixe hyperresponsiveness of the subepithelial tnicrocirculation". may develop in allergic airway diseases.

In a series of studies involving human and guinea-pig airways we have examined the mechanisms of mucosal exudation (luminal entry) of plasma [1.2] . The epithelial lining and the subepithelial network of microvesscis are key structures fbr this process. Topical stimulation with inllammatory mediators leads to active separation of endothelial cells in the post-capillary venules. Due to intravascular hydrostatic forces plasma is extravasated through open gaps in the venular wall. For isolated airway tissue expcrimetits it appears that a hydrostatic pressure of about 5 cm H^O. e.xerted on the basoiatera! aspects of epithelial cells, is sufficient to move the plasma macromolecules further across the epithelial lining [10.11] . The luminal entry of plasma is thus already produced by threshold inflammatory challenges, and it may occur without generation of oedema or increased lymph protein transport [17] . Sitice the tnovement of extravasalcd plasma into the airway lumen may not be much hindered by the normal epithelial lining the appearance of plasma exudation indices on the mucosal surface may promptly and specifically reflect the permeability of the subepithelial microcirculation.

The acute mediator-induced mucosal exudation of plasma is a unidirectional paraccllular flux of differentlysized solutes. The increased outward-directed "pertiieability' (exudation) is produced without changes of the mucosal inward-directed "permeability' (absorption) [18.19] . We have even observed that the mucosal absorption permeability is reduced in a subgroup of the present patients (men) during the present pollen season (as assessed with ^ Cr-F,DTA. a small polar solute similar in size to histamine) [20] . We therefore suggest that the increased responsiveness to histamine-challenge in the present study does not reflect increased mucosal absorption permeabilitv but is due to an increased responsiveness of the subepithelial microcircuiation. Furthermore, the magnitude of this vascular hyperresponsiveness is probably underestimated since, as a consequence of the previously demonstrated reduced mucosal absorptivit\ [20] . it is anticipated that less histamine reaches the microcirculation at the end of the pollen season compared with out of the season.

In this study we have used the "nasal pool'-device which permits concomitimt provocation and lavage from a large and reproducible airway mucosal surface area. We chose two concentrations of histamine. one of which is known to be a significant threshold exudative dose. The other concentration was five times stronger but still submaximal on the steep slope of the concentrationresponse curve [I5|. These concentrations of histamine were kept in direct contact with the nasal mucosa for 10 min which is a sufficient period fbr the exudative response to be fully or almost fully developed [15] . Although there were no changes in baseline levels of the proteins (saline challenge), the exudative response to both concentrations of histamine were significantly increased during seasonal pollen exposure. Subtraction of the baseline values from the histamine challenge values revealed similar results indicating that a shift to the left of the dose-response curve for topical histamine had occurred in seasonal allergic rhinitis. This exudative hyperresponsiveness of the airway microcirculation may reflect changes in the responsiveness of the vascular endothelial cells that regulate the permeability to plasma, or it may be a result of angiogenesis associated with prolonged allergic inllammation. However, whether these possibilities or other explanations are valid remains speculative. The histamine-itiduced nasal symptoms were not significantly increased during this ratber weak pollen season. However, the recording ol symptoms may be a much more coarse method than quantitation of plasma indices by employment of the nasal-pool device which olTers well controlled chailenge-lavage conditions.

The present results may be compared with observations reported by Majchel ef al. [21] who examined histamine challenge-induced effects in ragweed-induced rhinitis. Based on their results of histamine-induccd nasal symptoms, these authors concluded that hyperresponsiveness during the pollen season may be due to an increased baseline (i.e. seasonally induced "baseline' nasal symptomatology) and not to increased sensitivity to histamine per se. Majchet et al. [21] also measured albumin levels in the nasal lavage fluids after the histamine challenge and made the interesting observation that the histamine response (albumin levels) was higher at the peak than at the end of the pollen season. This particular effect remains unexplained since the authors [21] were not able to find significant changes during any part of the pollen season compared with the histamine-indueed albumin exudation/secretion out of the season. There are a number of aspects which need consideration when our study is compared with that of Majchel et al. [21] . Not only did we examine a weak birch pollen season with quite limited symptomatology, whereas Majchel et al. [21] worked with ragweed-allergic patients, who developed significant symptoms. The methodologies are also distinct. We applied specific concentrations of histamine on a large nasal mucosal surface area while Majchel et al. [21] sprayed different doses of hisiamine into the nostril. The peak output of albumin in our study was also about fivefold greater than that reported by Majchel et al. [21] . We cannot exclude the possibility that this discrepancy in part reflects the efficient washing exclusively of the exposed mucosal surface that is carried out by the present nasal pool device. Furthermore, in the present study we analysed three plasma proteins and could, therefore, secure that the recorded albumin levels reflected mucosal exudation of plasma and not secretory processes.

The correlation between albumin and o^-macroglobulin in the returned lavage fluid was excellent on both challenge occasions. This result agrees with the notion that histamine consistently produces mucosa! exudation of bulk non-sieved plasma. The luminal entry of tnmacroglobulin. well-known for its antiprotease activity, is of particular interest since this protein is highly capable of binding and targeting different cytokines [22, 23] . In airway inflammatory processes, a considerable amount of subepithelial (lamina propria) cytokine production and release may thus be transported to the airway surface by the exudation process. Hence, sampling of airway surface material during active exudative phases may yield important possibilities to monitor also subepithelial cytokine patterns in inflammatory airway diseases [24, 25] '.

It seems well established that a bronchial hyperresponsiveness to histamine challenges develops in subjects with seasonal rhinitis and asthma [26] [27] [28] [29] . However, it is not known what mechanisms or, indeed, which endorgan responses, in addition to bronchial smooth muscle, that are involved in bronchial hyperresponsiveness to histamine challenges. As flrst calculated by Hutt and Wick [30] , any increase in the thickness of tissue and surface layers between the bronchial smooth musele and the free airway lumen will in theory result in increased obstructive responsiveness to any bronchial constrictor. The plasma exudation response might increase the thickness of the lamina propria by increasing its content of fluid and matrix macromolecules. Equally, the mucosa! surface layer will be increased by a sticky and tenacious plasma exudate [31] . The exuded plasma also contains numerous proinflammatory peptides, oligoproteins, and proteins. An increased tendency for the exudative lesponse may, therefore, be of significance whether it oecurs in allergic airway disease (this study), common cold [14] or other forms of rhinitis, and in asthma.

We conclude that a microvascular exudative hyperresponsiveness may develop even in mild seasonal allergic rhinitis. Hence, exudative indices may be a more sensitive measure of airway inflammation in ongoing disease compared with acute inflammation. Furthermore, both the hyperresponsiveness and the maintained bulk nature of the mucosai exudation process {this study) strengthen the likelihood that all the multifactorial protein systems of plasma (e.g. coagulation and complement system together with iinmunoglobulins, fibronectin and other proteins) participate in airway mucosal inflammatory processes. We have previously demonstrated that a!so sensory nerve responsiveness (producing irritation and pain) may be increased in seasonal rhinitis [8] . The possibi!ity that a number of specific mucosa! endorgans have a!tered physio!ogica! responsiveness provides a novel concept of airway hyperresponsiveness with as yet unproven importanee for characterization of airway diseases, their pathogenesis, and their pharmacotherapy.
